present.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Foreign observers were present at the elections.
the gases present in the Earth’s atmosphere
present.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to be felt strongly or remembered for a long time
present.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The memory of her brother’s death is still present in her mind.
present.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: the present situation of the millions of people who are suffering poverty and disease
At the present time we have no explanation for this.
present.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: present
happening or existing now
The present situation could get much worse.
the present century
There are no plans to build more houses here at the present time.
current
present – used especially about something that is not expected to stay the same for long
current trends in fashion
the current state of the UK economy
existing
existing or being used now – used about things or situations that you think may be changed in the future
The existing offices are too small.
The proposal will strengthen existing immigration laws.
contemporary
used about the art, writing, ideas, society etc that belong to the present time
the impact of computer-generated imagery on contemporary art and design
contemporary music in Russia
today’s/of today
used about conditions and attitudes that exist now, when you are comparing them with those that existed in the past
People struggle to keep up with the pace of life in today’s world of instant communications.
the liberal ideology of today
present.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to give something to someone, for example at a formal or official occasion
present.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: He was presented with a bottle of champagne.
She was presented with an award.
The computer centre presented a cheque for £500 to cancer research.
present.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to cause something to happen or exist
present.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Large classes present great problems to many teachers.
I knew I had presented her with an impossible task.
present.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to show or describe someone or something
present.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: The artist was determined to present an accurate picture.
We’ll present the information using a chart.
Shakespeare presents the hero as a noble man doomed to make mistakes.
The government presents itself as being sensitive to environmental issues.
present.translation[1].definitions[3].de: to give a speech in which you offer an idea, plan etc to be considered or accepted
present.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: Our manager is due to present the report at the end of the month.
On January 3 the company will present its plans to the bank.
present.translation[1].definitions[4].de: to show something such as an official document or ticket to someone in an official position
present.translation[1].definitions[4].ex: You must present your passport to the customs officer.
present.translation[1].definitions[5].de: to give a performance in a theatre, cinema etc, or broadcast a programme on television or radio
present.translation[1].definitions[5].ex: Edinburgh Theatre Company presents ‘The Wind in the Willows’.
present.translation[1].definitions[6].de: if you present a television or radio programme, you introduce its different parts
present.translation[1].definitions[6].ex: Thursday’s ‘The Late Show’ was presented by Cynthia Rose.
present.translation[1].definitions[7].de: to give something or someone a particular appearance or style
present.translation[1].definitions[7].ex: The restaurant likes to present food with style.
present.translation[1].definitions[8].de: to formally introduce someone to another person, especially to someone of a very high rank
present.translation[1].definitions[8].ex: I was presented to the Queen in 1964.
present.translation[1].definitions[9].de: to show an illness by having a particular symptom (=sign of an illness)
present.translation[1].definitions[9].ex: The doctor asked whether any of the children had been presenting any unusual symptoms.
Three of the five patients presented with fever and severe headaches.
present.translation[1].note_box[0].headi: – Meaning 2: to cause something to happen or exist
present.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: These mountain roads present problems even to experienced drivers.
Juggling work and family responsibilities presents difficulties for women.
I'm enjoying my new job because it presents an interesting challenge.
The disease presents a grave threat to the livestock industry.
The lack of money presented a massive obstacle.
present.translation[2].definitions[0].de: something you give someone on a special occasion or to thank them for something
present.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: I’m looking for a present for Mark.
present.translation[2].note_box[0].secti: I was given this book as a present.
I want to buy a present for Lucy but I’m not sure what she’d like.
Did you get Bill a birthday present?
Children soon learn to enjoy giving presents as well as getting them.
She spent the afternoon wrapping Christmas presents.
Can we open our presents now?
We always exchange Christmas and birthday presents.
What would Dad like as a Christmas present?
His wedding present to her had been a diamond necklace.
present.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to make a speech introducing an idea, plan etc to be considered
present.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: a lack of evidence presented by prosecutors
The company has until July to restructure its debt and present an operating plan to its creditors.
present.translation[3].definitions[1].de: to produce a document, such as a ticket or pass, for an official to check
present.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: When a shopper presents a supermarket ID card, the purchases can be linked to his or her name and address.
To receive care, every patient will need to present a health insurance card to the hospital or doctor.
present.translation[3].definitions[2].de: if something presents an opportunity, advantage, problem etc, it creates it
present.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: With interest rates slightly above 8%, the securities present an attractive alternative to stocks.
Microsoft’s Windows presents the most formidable technical challenge ever to the Macintosh.
